These are just a few ideas that don‚Äôt always find a home inside the national security consensus. 

But I‚Äôve worked w many on Biden‚Äôs team and I know they are willing to work with progressives - and anyone else with new, good ideas - to make American foreign policy more nimble.

9/ Restore America‚Äôs commitment to a two-state future in the Middle East. Take a hard line on new settlements and annexation. Restore funding for humanitarian programs in the PA. Being an ally of Israel‚Äôs security means charting a path to a Palestinian state.

8/ Let‚Äôs stop blindly fueling a dangerous arms race in the Middle East. The equipment we send to UAE ends up w extremist militias. The bombs we send to Saudi end up killing kids in Yemen. And it all just leads to an Iranian arms buildup. Let‚Äôs be more judicious in arms sales.

7/ Foreign policy must = climate policy. But diplomacy alone can‚Äôt save the planet. We need hard dollars for America to spend abroad to help developing nations cover to clean energy. Billions for a supersized Green Climate Fund.

6/ Progressives don‚Äôt hate trade deals - just trade deals that are written for corporations instead of workers and citizens. Let‚Äôs do a new Asia trade agreement, but one that is written to protect wages, not profits and shareholder returns.

5/ No military action without congressional authorization. Yes, it‚Äôs hard to get sign off from Congress for a military strike. But for good reason. Americans are rightly skeptical about military action, and that‚Äôs why the Constitution vests the war making power in Congress.

4/ Sanctions can have impact, but their overuse is risking making the tactic feckless. Too often the are just a box checking exercise. Or they hurt orindary people while not changing the behavior of foreign regimes. We need to be much more strategic in our sanctions use.

3/ Choose to fight Russia symmetrically. That means plussing up counter-propaganda, anti-corruption, and energy independence programming on Russia‚Äôs periphery. In general, we need more non-military tools in our foreign policy toolkit.
2/ Secret wars, exempt from public view or oversight, too often go off the rails. For example, our drone program more often kills the wrong target, adding fuel to extremist groups recruitment drives.

1/ For instance, it‚Äôs time for America to finally shake our hubris of what can be accomplished by military deployments in far off places. Restraint IS a policy. Often our intervention (think Iraq or Libya or Syria) ends up doing much more harm than good.
